what: Structure of panel data causal inference problems
title: Panel Treatment Effects Tools
text: ptetools package compartmentalizes steps needed implement estimators group-time average treatment effects (aggregations) order make easier apply sorts arguments outside “birthplace” literature difference--differences. Essentially, idea many panel data causal inference problems involve steps : Defining identification strategy (e.g., difference--differences) Defining notion group (e.g., based treatment timing) Looping groups time periods Organizing data correct data show group time period Computing group-time average treatment effects (parameters local group time period) Aggregating group-time average treatment effect parameters (e.g., event study overall average treatment effect parameter) Many steps common across different panel data causal inference settings. example, implement difference--differences identification strategy change--changes identification strategy steps except replacing step 1. idea ptetools package re-use much code/infrastructure possible developing new approaches panel data causal inference. example, ptetools sits “backend” several packages including: ife, contdid, parts qte.

title: Panel Treatment Effects Tools
text: main function called pte. important parameters takes subset_fun attgt_fun. functions user pass pte. subset_fun takes overall data, group, time period, possibly arguments returns data.frame containing relevant subset data, outcome, whether unit considered treated comparison group group/time. one example relevant subset function provided package: two_by_two_subset function. function takes original dataset, subsets pre- post-treatment periods denotes treated untreated units. particular subset perhaps common/important one thinking treatment effects panel data, function can reused across applications. main function attgt_fun. function able take correct subset data, possibly along arguments function, report ATT subset. minor modification, function available sort treatment effects application — example, can solve baseline 2x2 case difference differences, use function , ptetools package take care dealing variation treatment timing. attgt_fun returns influence function, ptetools package also conduct inference using multiplier bootstrap (fast) produce uniform confidence bands (adjust multiple testing). default output pte overall treatment effect treated (.e., across groups participate treatment time period) event study. aggregations possible, seem leading cases; aggregations group-time average treatment effects discussed length Callaway Sant’Anna (2021). several examples ptetools package can used implement identification strategy small amount new code.

title: Panel Treatment Effects Tools
text: package, based Callaway Sant’Anna (2021), includes estimates group-time average treatment effects, ATT(g,t), based difference differences identification strategy. following example demonstrates easy compute group-time average treatment effects using difference differences using ptetools package. [Note: definitely recommended way little error handling, etc. , rather proof concept. use package case.] example reproduces estimates effect minimum wage employment using data package.  ’s interesting , “new” code needs write did_attgt function. see small amount code.
code: library(did) data(mpdta) did_res <- pte(   yname = "lemp",   gname = "first.treat",   tname = "year",   idname = "countyreal",   data = mpdta,   setup_pte_fun = setup_pte,   subset_fun = two_by_two_subset,   attgt_fun = did_attgt,   xformla = ~lpop )  summary(did_res) #>  #> Overall ATT:   #>      ATT    Std. Error     [ 95%  Conf. Int.]   #>  -0.0305         0.013     -0.056     -0.0049 * #>  #>  #> Dynamic Effects: #>  Event Time Estimate Std. Error   [95%  Conf. Band]   #>          -3   0.0298     0.0143 -0.0048      0.0643   #>          -2  -0.0024     0.0142 -0.0370      0.0321   #>          -1  -0.0243     0.0122 -0.0538      0.0053   #>           0  -0.0189     0.0148 -0.0547      0.0169   #>           1  -0.0536     0.0193 -0.1004     -0.0067 * #>           2  -0.1363     0.0390 -0.2307     -0.0418 * #>           3  -0.1008     0.0331 -0.1809     -0.0207 * #> --- #> Signif. codes: `*' confidence band does not cover 0 ggpte(did_res)

what: Example 2: Policy Evaluation during a Pandemic

text: next example, consider trying estimate effects COVID-19 related policies pandemic. estimates effects state-level shelter--place orders early part pandemic. data example comes ppe package can loaded running Callaway Li (2021) argue particular unconfoundedness-type strategy appropriate context -type strategies due spread COVID-19 cases highly nonlinear. However, still deal challenge variation treatment timing. Therefore, still useful think group-time average treatment effects, strategy replaced particular unconfoundedness type assumption. ptetools package particularly useful .  ’s interesting just little code needs written . new code required ppe::covid_attgt function available , , can see, simple.

title: Panel Treatment Effects Tools
text: code used multiplier bootstrap. great thing multiplier bootstrap ’s fast. order use , work influence function estimator ATT(g,t). Although pretty much always end , can tedious, can nice get working version code project going working details influence function. ptetools package can used empirical bootstrap. limitations. First, ’s going substantially slower. Second, code just reports pointwise confidence intervals. However, basically set fit typical workflow, see way get preliminary results. Let’s demonstrate . , consider setup Example 1, influence function returned. Let’s write code : Now, can show sorts results  ’s exciting just little new code needs written.
code: # did with no influence function did_attgt_noif <- function(gt_data, xformla, ...) {   # call original function   did_gt <- did_attgt(gt_data, xformla, ...)    # remove influence function   did_gt$inf_func <- NULL    did_gt } did_res_noif <- pte(   yname = "lemp",   gname = "first.treat",   tname = "year",   idname = "countyreal",   data = mpdta,   setup_pte_fun = setup_pte,   subset_fun = two_by_two_subset,   attgt_fun = did_attgt_noif, # this is only diff.   xformla = ~lpop )  summary(did_res_noif) #>  #> Overall ATT:   #>      ATT    Std. Error     [ 95%  Conf. Int.]   #>  -0.0323        0.0128    -0.0574     -0.0071 * #>  #>  #> Dynamic Effects: #>  Event Time Estimate Std. Error [95% Pointwise  Conf. Band]   #>          -3   0.0269     0.0110          0.0053      0.0485 * #>          -2  -0.0050     0.0133         -0.0311      0.0211   #>          -1  -0.0229     0.0152         -0.0526      0.0069   #>           0  -0.0201     0.0124         -0.0445      0.0042   #>           1  -0.0547     0.0166         -0.0872     -0.0222 * #>           2  -0.1382     0.0372         -0.2111     -0.0653 * #>           3  -0.1069     0.0392         -0.1836     -0.0302 * #> --- #> Signif. codes: `*' confidence band does not cover 0 ggpte(did_res_noif)

title: Aggregated Treatment Effects Class — aggte_obj
code: aggte_obj(   overall.att = NULL,   overall.se = NULL,   type = "simple",   egt = NULL,   att.egt = NULL,   se.egt = NULL,   crit.val.egt = NULL,   inf.function = NULL,   min_e = NULL,   max_e = NULL,   balance_e = NULL,   DIDparams = NULL )

title: Aggregated Treatment Effects Class — aggte_obj
text: overall.att estimated overall ATT overall.se Standard error overall ATT type type aggregation done.  Default "overall". egt Holds length exposure (dynamic effects), group (selective treatment timing), time period (calendar time effects) att.egt ATT specific egt se.egt standard error specific egt crit.val.egt critical value computing uniform confidence bands dynamic effects, selective treatment timing, time period effects. inf.function influence function chosen aggregated parameters min_e minimum event time computed event study results. useful huge number pre-treatment periods. max_e maximum event time computed event study results. useful huge number post-treatment periods. balance_e Drops groups least balance_e periods post-treatment data.  keeps composition groups constant across different event times event study. Default NULL, case ignored. DIDparams DIDparams object

title: Heavy-Lifting for pte Function — compute.pte

title: Heavy-Lifting for pte Function — compute.pte
text: ptep pte_params object subset_fun function take data, g (group), tp (time period), ... able return appropriate data.frame can used attgt_fun produce ATT(g=g,t=tp).  data frame constructed using gt_data_frame order guarantee appropriate columns identify group observation belongs , etc. attgt_fun function work case single group "right" number time periods recover estimate ATT.  example, contest difference differences, need work single group, find appropriate comparison group (untreated units), find right time periods (pre- post-treatment), recover estimate ATT group.  called separately groups time periods compute ATT(g,t)'s. function needs work specific way.  take arguments: data, ....  data constructed using function gt_data_frame checks make sure data correct columns defined. ... additional arguments (formulas covariates) attgt_fun needs.  arguments attgt_fun must return list element ATT containing group-time average treatment effect group time period. attgt_fun returns influence function (provided list element named inf_func), code use multiplier bootstrap compute standard errors group-time average treatment effects, overall treatment effect parameter, dynamic treatment effect parameter (.e., event study parameter).  attgt_fun return influence function, objects computed using empirical bootstrap.  usually (perhaps substantially) easier code, also usually (perhaps substantially) computationally slower. ... extra arguments can passed create correct subsets data (depending subset_fun), estimate group time average treatment effects (depending attgt_fun), aggregating treatment effects (particularly useful min_e, max_e, balance_e arguments event study aggregations)

title: Difference-in-differences for ATT(g,t) — did_attgt
text: Takes data.frame computes particular group g time period t computes estimate group time average treatment effect corresponding influence function using difference differences approach. code relies gt_data certain variables defined. particular, id column (individual identifier), D (treated group identifier), period (time period), name (equal "pre" pre-treatment periods equal "post" post treatment periods), Y (outcome). case, call two_by_two_subset sets data format call did_attgt.

title: Difference-in-differences for ATT(g,t) — did_attgt

Main use case one-shot imputation estimators.  supported yet. time_period_fun Logical indicating whether untreated potential outcomes can estimated groups time period.  supported yet. group_fun Logical indicating whether untreated potential outcomes can estimated time periods single group.  supported yet. functions aim reducing eliminating running code multiple times. process_dtt_gt_fun optional function customize results gt-specific function returns distribution treated untreated potential outcomes.  default process_dtt_gt, function provided package.  See function example function return.  unused unused except cases results involve distributions. process_dose_gt_fun optional function customize results gt-specific function returns treatment effects depend dose (.e., amount treatment).  default process_dose_gt, function provided package.  See function example function return.  unused except cases results involve doses. biters number bootstrap iterations; default 100 cl number clusters used bootstrapping; default 1 call keeps track call external functions/packages ... extra arguments can passed create correct subsets data (depending subset_fun), estimate group time average treatment effects (depending attgt_fun), aggregating treatment effects (particularly useful min_e, max_e, balance_e arguments event study aggregations)

title: Panel Treatment Effects — pte

title: Panel Treatment Effects — pte
text: Maintainer: Brantly Callaway brantly.callaway@uga.edu

title: Panel Treatment Effects — pte
code: # example using minimum wage data # and difference-in-differences identification strategy library(did) data(mpdta) did_res <- suppressWarnings(   pte(     yname = "lemp",     gname = "first.treat",     tname = "year",     idname = "countyreal",     data = mpdta,     setup_pte_fun = setup_pte,     subset_fun = two_by_two_subset,     attgt_fun = did_attgt,     xformla = ~lpop   ) )  summary(did_res) #>  #> Overall ATT:   #>      ATT    Std. Error     [ 95%  Conf. Int.]   #>  -0.0305        0.0118    -0.0535     -0.0074 * #>  #>  #> Dynamic Effects: #>  Event Time Estimate Std. Error   [95%  Conf. Band]   #>          -3   0.0298     0.0167 -0.0086      0.0681   #>          -2  -0.0024     0.0120 -0.0300      0.0251   #>          -1  -0.0243     0.0105 -0.0484     -0.0001 * #>           0  -0.0189     0.0148 -0.0529      0.0150   #>           1  -0.0536     0.0171 -0.0928     -0.0144 * #>           2  -0.1363     0.0378 -0.2228     -0.0497 * #>           3  -0.1008     0.0402 -0.1928     -0.0089 * #> --- #> Signif. codes: `*' confidence band does not cover 0 #>  ggpte(did_res)

title: General ATT(g,t) — pte_attgt

Default FALSE. est_method type estimation method use. Default "dr" doubly robust.  option "reg" regression adjustment. ... extra function arguments; used

title: Default, General Function for Computing Treatment Effects with Panel Data — pte_default
code: pte_default(   yname,   gname,   tname,   idname,   data,   xformula = ~1,   d_outcome = FALSE,   d_covs_formula = ~-1,   lagged_outcome_cov = FALSE,   est_method = "dr",   anticipation = 0,   base_period = "varying",   control_group = "notyettreated",   weightsname = NULL,   cband = TRUE,   alp = 0.05,   boot_type = "multiplier",   biters = 100,   cl = 1 )

title: Default, General Function for Computing Treatment Effects with Panel Data — pte_default
text: yname Name outcome data gname Name group data tname Name time period data idname Name id data data balanced panel data xformula one-sided formula covariates used propensity score outcome regression models d_outcome Whether take first difference outcome. default FALSE.  use difference--differences, set TRUE. d_covs_formula formula time varying covariates enter first estimation step models.  default include , , hence, include pre-treatment covariates. lagged_outcome_cov Whether include lagged outcome covariate. Default FALSE. est_method type estimation method use. Default "dr" doubly robust.  option "reg" regression adjustment. anticipation many periods treatment actually takes place can effect outcomes base_period type base period use.  affects numeric value results pre-treatment periods.  Results post-treatment periods affected choice.  default "varying", base period "back " immediately preceding period pre-treatment periods.  option "universal" base period fixed pre-treatment periods period right treatment starts.  "Universal" commonly used difference--differences applications, can unnatural identification strategies. control_group group used comparison group. default choice "notyettreated", different estimation strategies can implement choices control group weightsname name column contains sampling weights. default NULL, case sampling weights used. cband whether report uniform (instead pointwise) confidence band (default TRUE) alp significance level; default 0.05 boot_type one "multiplier" (default) "empirical". multiplier bootstrap generally much faster, attgt_fun needs provide expression influence function (challenging figure ).  influence function provided, pte package use empirical bootstrap matter value parameter. biters number bootstrap iterations; default 100 cl number clusters used bootstrapping; default 1

title: Default, General Function for Computing Treatment Effects with Panel Data — pte_default
code: # example using minimum wage data # and a lagged outcome unconfoundedness strategy library(did) data(mpdta) lou_res <- suppressWarnings(   pte_default(     yname = "lemp",     gname = "first.treat",     tname = "year",     idname = "countyreal",     data = mpdta,     xformula = ~lpop,     d_outcome = FALSE,     d_covs_formula = ~lpop,     lagged_outcome_cov = TRUE   ) )  summary(lou_res) #>  #> Overall ATT:   #>     ATT    Std. Error     [ 95%  Conf. Int.]   #>  -0.037        0.0126    -0.0618     -0.0122 * #>  #>  #> Dynamic Effects: #>  Event Time Estimate Std. Error   [95%  Conf. Band]   #>          -3   0.0262     0.0130 -0.0073      0.0597   #>          -2  -0.0100     0.0151 -0.0490      0.0290   #>          -1  -0.0222     0.0173 -0.0669      0.0225   #>           0  -0.0266     0.0120 -0.0577      0.0045   #>           1  -0.0448     0.0167 -0.0881     -0.0015 * #>           2  -0.1312     0.0422 -0.2404     -0.0220 * #>           3  -0.0968     0.0323 -0.1804     -0.0133 * #> --- #> Signif. codes: `*' confidence band does not cover 0 #>  ggpte(lou_res)
